### Knowns and Unknowns
#### with custom styling

The term is used to explain that any model of the future can only be informed by information that is currently available to the observer and, as such, faces substantial limitations and unknown risk.

> There are known knowns; there are things we know that we know.\
  There are known unknowns; that is to say, there are things that we now know we don’t know.\
  But there are also unknown unknowns; there are things we do not know we don’t know.\
--- United States Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld\

KNOWN KNOWNS: Discovered and readily available information for analysis.

UNKNOWN KNOWNS: This information exists, but I never looked for it, or found it. Undiscovered information which may be available for analysis.

KNOWN UNKNOWNS: I need this information but cannot find it. I don’t have this information, and I’m not sure if it exists.

UNKNOWN UNKNOWNS: The term unknown unknown refers to circumstances or outcomes that were not conceived of by an observer at a given point in time

### Uncertainty
#### with custom styling

Causes of Uncertainty

Schmitt and Klein (1996) identified four sources of uncertainty: missing information, unreliable information, ambiguous or conflicting information, and complex information.

Measures of Uncertainty

Variability
Noise
Incompleteness
Indeterminacy
Bias
Error
Accuracy
Precision
Reliability
Validity
Quality
Integrity
